guidelines.condition: direct_experience && witnessing_the_event && traumatic_event_occurred_to && repetitive_or_extreme && memories_of_the_traumatic && distressing_dreams_of_the && dissociative_reactions && intense_or_prolonged && marked_physiological && efforts_to_avoid_distressing && efforts_to_avoid_external && inability_to_remember && persistent_and_exaggerated && persistent_or_distorted && persistent_negative_emotional && markedly_diminished_interest && feelings_of_detachment_or && persistent_inability_to && irritable_behavior_and_angry && 'reckless_or_self-destructive' && hypervigilance && exaggerated_startle_response && problems_with_concentration && sleep_disturbance && duration_of_the_disturbance && causes_clinically_significant && not_attributable_to && depersonalization && derealization && full_diagnostic_criteria_6

children.text:
## DSM-5 criteria for Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD)

An assessment score that assists the diagnosis of Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) using the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5) Criteria. The DSM-5 criteria for PTSD consists of 27 items divided into six categories:

- Exposure (4 items)
- Intrusion symptoms (5 items)
- Avoidance (2 items)
- Altered mood (7 items)
- Altered reactivity (6 items)
- Additional required criteria (3 items).



Additionally, the diagnosis of PTSD can be accompanied by two types of subsets: dissociative symptoms (Depersonalization and/or Derealization) and/or Delayed Expression.
A. Exposure to actual or threatened death, serious injury, or sexual violence in one (or more) of the following ways:

children.label: A1. Directly experiencing the traumatic event(s).
children.name: direct_experience

children.label: A2. Witnessing, in person, the event(s) as it occurred to others.
children.name: witnessing_the_event

children.label: A3. Learning that the traumatic event(s) occurred to a close family member or close friend. In cases of actual or threatened death of a family member or friend, the event(s) must have been violent or accidental.
children.name: traumatic_event_occurred_to

children.label: A4. Experiencing repeated or extreme exposure to aversive details of the traumatic event(s) (e.g., first responders collecting human remains; police officers repeatedly exposed to details of child abuse).
children.name: repetitive_or_extreme
children.helpertext: Note: Criterion A4 does not apply to exposure through electronic media, television, movies, or pictures, unless this exposure is work related.

children.text: B. Presence of one (or more) of the following intrusion symptoms associated with the traumatic event(s), beginning after the traumatic event(s) occurred:

children.label: B1. Recurrent, involuntary, and intrusive distressing memories of the traumatic event(s).
children.name: memories_of_the_traumatic
children.helpertext: Note: In children older than 6 years, repetitive play may occur in which themes or aspects of the traumatic event(s) are expressed.

children.label: B2. Recurrent distressing dreams in which the content and/or affect of the dream are related to the traumatic event(s).
children.name: distressing_dreams_of_the
children.helpertext: Note: In children, there may be frightening dreams without recognizable content.

children.label: B3. Dissociative reactions (e.g., flashbacks) in which the individual feels or acts as if the traumatic event(s) were recurring. (Such reactions may occur on a continuum, with the most extreme expression being a complete loss of awareness of present surroundings.)
children.name: dissociative_reactions
children.helpertext: Note: In children, trauma-specific reenactment may occur in play.

children.label: B4. Intense or prolonged psychological distress at exposure to internal or external cues that symbolize or resemble an aspect of the traumatic event(s).
children.name: intense_or_prolonged

children.label: B5. Marked physiological reactions to internal or external cues that symbolize or resemble an aspect of the traumatic event(s).
children.name: marked_physiological

children.text: C. Persistent avoidance of stimuli associated with the traumatic event(s), beginning after the traumatic event(s) occurred, as evidenced by one or both of the following:

children.label: C1. Avoidance of or efforts to avoid distressing memories, thoughts, or feelings about or closely associated with the traumatic event(s).
children.name: efforts_to_avoid_distressing

children.label: C2. Avoidance of or efforts to avoid external reminders (people, places, conversations, activities, objects, situations) that arouse distressing memories, thoughts, or feelings about or closely associated with the traumatic event(s).
children.name: efforts_to_avoid_external

children.text: D. Negative alterations in cognitions and mood associated with the traumatic event(s), beginning or worsening after the traumatic event(s) occurred, as evidenced by two (or more) of the following:

children.label: D1. Inability to remember an important aspect of the traumatic event(s) (typically due to dissociative amnesia and not to other factors such as head injury, alcohol, or drugs).
children.name: inability_to_remember

children.label: D2. Persistent and exaggerated negative beliefs or expectations about oneself, others, or the world (e.g., “I am bad,” “No one can be trusted,” “The world is completely dangerous,” “My whole nervous system is permanently ruined”).
children.name: persistent_and_exaggerated

children.label: D3. Persistent, distorted cognitions about the cause or consequences of the traumatic event(s) that lead the individual to blame himself/herself or others.
children.name: persistent_or_distorted

children.label: D4. Persistent negative emotional state (e.g., fear, horror, anger, guilt, or shame).
children.name: persistent_negative_emotional

children.label: D5. Markedly diminished interest or participation in significant activities.
children.name: markedly_diminished_interest

children.label: D6. Feelings of detachment or estrangement from others.
children.name: feelings_of_detachment_or

children.label: D7. Persistent inability to experience positive emotions (e.g., inability to experience happiness, satisfaction, or loving feelings).
children.name: persistent_inability_to

children.text: E. Marked alterations in arousal and reactivity associated with the traumatic event, beginning or worsening after the traumatic event occurred, as evidenced by ≥2 of the following:

children.label: E1. Irritable behavior and angry outbursts (with little or no provocation) typically expressed as verbal or physical aggression toward people or objects.
children.name: irritable_behavior_and_angry

children.label: E2. Reckless or self-destructive behavior.
children.name: reckless_or_self-destructive

children.label: E3. Hypervigilance.
children.name: hypervigilance

children.label: E4. Exaggerated startle response.
children.name: exaggerated_startle_response

children.label: E5. Problems with concentration.
children.name: problems_with_concentration

children.label: E6. Sleep disturbance (e.g., difficulty falling or staying asleep or restless sleep).
children.name: sleep_disturbance

children.label: F. Duration of the disturbance (Criteria B, C, D, and E) is more than 1 month.
children.name: duration_of_the_disturbance

children.label: G. The disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.
children.name: causes_clinically_significant

children.label: H. The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., medication, alcohol) or another medical condition.
children.name: not_attributable_to

children.label: Persistent or recurrent experiences of feeling detached from, and as if one were an outside observer of, one’s mental processes or body (e.g., feeling as though one were in a dream; feeling a sense of unreality of self or body or of time moving slowly).
children.name: depersonalization

children.label: Persistent or recurrent experiences of unreality of surroundings (e.g., the world around the individual is experienced as unreal, dreamlike, distant, or distorted).
children.name: derealization

children.label: If the full diagnostic criteria are not met until at least 6 months after the event (although the onset and expression of some symptoms may be immediate).
children.name: full_diagnostic_criteria_6

children.label: Exposure Score
children.name: exposure_score

children.label: Intrusion symptoms Score
children.name: intrusion_symptoms_score

children.label: Avoidance Score
children.name: avoidance_score

children.label: Altered mood Score
children.name: altered_mood_score

children.label: Altered reactivity Score
children.name: altered_reactivity_score

children.label: Additional required criteria Score
children.name: additional_required_criteria

children.label: Interpretation
children.name: interpretation

children.label: Reset
